sub_topic: The chaotic dynamics of the Belousov-Zhabotinsky reaction
message_1:
A researcher is experimenting with the Belousov-Zhabotinsky reaction to study its chaotic dynamics. The researcher measures the concentration of the reacting species over time and obtains the following data:

Time (s)      | Concentration (M)
------------- | ------------------
0             | 0.01
20            | 0.03
40            | 0.02
60            | 0.04
80            | 0.06
100           | 0.01
120           | 0.03
140           | 0.02
160           | 0.04
180           | 0.05
200           | 0.01

Assuming that the reaction follows a chaotic behavior, using the method of Lyapunov exponents, calculate the maximum Lyapunov exponent of this system, rounded to two decimal places.
message_2:
To calculate the maximum Lyapunov exponent, we first need to create a time-delayed phase space plot using the given data. We can use the method of delays with a delay time τ and an embedding dimension m. However, since we don't have enough information to determine the appropriate values for τ and m, we cannot accurately calculate the maximum Lyapunov exponent for this system.

In general, calculating the Lyapunov exponent requires a more extensive dataset and a deeper understanding of the underlying dynamics of the system. The given data is not sufficient to perform this calculation.
